At Mon, 14 Dec 2009 19:23:19 +0100,
Claudio Martella wrote:
> 
> Hello,
> 
=
> I've warchived a site with heritrix 3.0. Now, with my own java program
> =
i'm trying to put the content into my solr index server.
> 
> The actual co=
de prints unexpected (to me) results:
> 
> 
> ArchiveReader r =3D WARCReade=
rFactory.get(arcFile);
> r.setDigest(true);
> for (ArchiveRecord rec : r) {=

>                 if (rec !=3D null) {
>                     ArchiveRecord=
Header meta =3D rec.getHeader();
>                     System.out.println(m=
eta.getUrl() + ": "+
> meta.getMimetype().trim());
>                     ..=
.
> 
> which prints, i.e.:
> 
> http://www.tis.bz.it/doc-bereiche/gz_doc/pi=
c/gruenderunt/gikispy.jpg:
> application/http; msgtype=3Dresponse
> http://=
www.tis.bz.it/doc-bereiche/gz_doc/pic/gruenderunt/gikispy.jpg:
> applicatio=
n/http; msgtype=3Drequest
> http://www.tis.bz.it/doc-bereiche/gz_doc/pic/gr=
uenderunt/gikispy.jpg:
> application/warc-fields
> 
> which is weird as the=
 mime-type is application/http (what is it?) for a
> jpg, PLUS i have three=
 records for each URL.
> 
> Any idea?

Hi Claudio -

See information about =
the WARC specification [1] for why it contains 3
records for each URL. Heri=
trix stores the complete HTTP request and
response for each URL fetched, pl=
us additional information. Each is
stored in a different record.

As for ho=
w to deal with these using ArchiveReader, I am not sure. I
have only dealt =
with ARC files in Heritrix. If you simply want to
index the first step woul=
d be ignoring records with mimetype
=E2=80=9Capplication/http; msgtype=3Dre=
quest=E2=80=9D and =E2=80=9Capplication/warc-fields=E2=80=9D.
After that yo=
u would need to parse the record.

1. http://www.digitalpreservation.gov/fo=
rmats/fdd/fdd000236.shtml

best,
Erik Hetzner
